Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.

How responsive to student comments was the instructor?

I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Henry Glick  Sometimes, as a beginner in spatial statistics, I felt like Henry was maybe too smart or I just wasn't grasping what he would try to convey. Overall though, I think Henry was a fantastic TA.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Very helpful on practical issues.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Very knowledgable about the subject and very good at explaining information.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was very helpful in office hours, very knowledgeable about R, GIS, and data work in general. I also appreciated the email and documents he complied with helpful code, notes, and resources.

Instructor: Henry Glick  Very willing to dig in on your R code and troubleshoot. It's tough having only a single TA for a class like this, because each person's problems are so specialized, so almost need to be able to schedule time to meet instead of open office hours.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Incredibly knowledgeable. Henry was able to answer all of my questions so quickly.
Instructor: Henry Glick  Henry was thoughtful TA. He assisted us on our project especially on how to use R.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Two excellent professors, with very complementary teaching styles!
I sometimes felt that the material was covered a little quickly and at too high a level. I would have liked going into more depth on some topics (with derivations, proofs, etc.)

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The material is of high relevance for my future work
Very self-directed.
The freedom to apply the concepts learned to our own data
I enjoyed working on the final project and learning R.
All the R scripts prepared by the instructors
The lectures were excellent The example code was super useful The demonstration helped clarify the lectures
a very good survey could into spatial statistics
Spatial statistical analysis is essential to understanding environmental conditions.
The lab section and flexible time of TA and Jonathan were the best aspect of the course

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I would actually encourage more assignments (if even credit/no credit) throughout the semester. It's easy to put things to the side without weekly or biweekly pushes, and this material is really best-learned through hands on experience.
I think weekly non-graded or graded-on-attendance lab sessions playing around with the techniques in R would be extremely helpful.

For the material that Tim teaches, I think it would be helpful to focus less on giving us the references for further information during lectures (this could easily be provided via email), and to spend time on the material that you are teaching. While I appreciate when Tim acknowledges he is less familiar with a certain subject than what he is an expert it, if the instructor feels like they can't expand on a topic more than just a sentence or two about it, I dont think more time in class needs to be spent on it, as it may confuse others. Also, I really liked it at the end when we used the computers in the CSSSI during class. I think it would be helpful to use these more often throughout the semester to become more comfortable with the techniques. Finally, I think some sort of additional session at the beginning of the semester--either as part of the class or a separate session--on how to read geospatial data into R would be SUPER helpful. A lot of time was spent trying to understand the differences between classes of spatial data and which types worked with what packages. Some more guidance on the topic would be much appreciated!

I think it would be helpful to have some more class "lab" time in the CSSSI computer class room, like we had that one day at the end of the semester. I also think having some more concrete problem sets to work on (even if they are ungraded) would be helpful in learning R and applying the methods from lecture.
More hands-on classwork, more structure

I think having 1-2 short problem sets would have been valuable. In addition, I'm still not completely sure which tools we studied are used in practice in academic articles, perhaps it depends on the field.
more assignments would be helpful to help us learn about applying techniques in this course

The course needs a way for students to complete periodic work and then check it or have it checked to know if one is doing the work correctly. The course probably goes too rapidly. This is a hard call, since one also wants to garner as much information as possible.
It needs more lab section.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: More stat lab sessions would have been helpful. The few that were held were effective and important for identifying points on which I was personally unclear.
I think weekly non-graded or graded-on-attendance lab sessions playing around with the techniques in R would be extremely helpful.
I thought that the class during which we had a short coding assignment and worked in CSSSI was very helpful.

Need a discussion/lab section. Or perhaps offer a set of optional problem sets with an optional lab section that people realize to be effectively part of the course. would go a long way towards staying engaged, I often thought I understood the lectures until push came to shove in executing the R scripts.
N/A
It was very effective. it would be great if the lab section is given more.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Relevant for my future academic work.
Very relevant to my research.

This course was a good introduction to spatial statistics and R. I had never heard of spatial statistics before this, so now I know that it exists and what some of the main tools are if/when I want to use them in my research.
interested in spatial arrangements driven by urban land-use
I study economics, I enjoyed the course and learned a lot but I still haven't seen most of the tools taught used in econ articles (even those dealing with spatial issues) and I'm not sure why
I took the course more for understanding than because I expect to do statistical analyses. The fit is good.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Same as above.
To help with my research, which is all about spatial data.
To learn about spatial statistics.
I was looking for a fun, different last course in which I could learn a new coding language and pick up some statistical skills.
get more fluent in stats, like space
Interested in environmental economics and spatial issues could be relevant + wanted to improve GIS+R skils
wanted to learn about techniques related to spatial statistics
Repeated: I took the course more for understanding than because I expect to do statistical analyses.
To improve my skills on spatial statistic theory and its application on environmental field. doing the project was the best opportunity to learn several techniques gained in the class.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, though I wish I had examined more of the material throughout the course of the semester.
Yes. Although I'm a little surprised at how much freedom there is in choosing spatial analysis techniques.
Yes, but I was hoping to use more of GIS.
Yes.
somewhat, stats is always a lifelong learning curve
Yes
more assignments would be helpful
Yes
Yes and no. The course move very rapidly; it will take some review on my part to be sure I have grasped most of the major concepts and many of the skills.
Yes! it gave me a strong foundation on the application of spatial statistics in environmental field

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Push yourself to practice exercises, adjust the demo scripts, etc. as you go through the course.
Good course, structured not to be stressful, and I learned a lot. Very project-based.
Useful class on spatial statistics. Low required workload but you really get out of it what you put into it.

If you are self-motivated to practice the material presented in class, this course is great and you will get a lot out of it. If you need lots of assignments and tests as a commitment device to learn the material, this is not going to be a good course for you.
Pick your dataset first thing, and after each lecture run your data through the R code instead of waiting until the end. Schedule standing office hours each week with jonathan to keep you on track.
As the instructors said what you get out of the course depends on the effort you put into it
a high level of advanced knowledge in statistics would help

If spatial statistics is integral to your field or if the topic interests you, take the course. The professors are both very responsive to student needs, very approachable, very knowledgeable in their fields, very good lecturers -- if on the faster side. The course project is a good idea and forces one (in a good way) to engage with some of the material of the course.

For those who interested on the application of statistics on evaluating or measuring spatial relationship of environmental problems or phenomenon, this course will give you the technique on how to do it. It would be helpful if you already know what project do you want to work since the beginning of the course and find your data as soon as possible. then you can set up regular meetings with the lecturers and TA to consult the project.
